facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 559 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICT1ON Civil Appeal No. 559 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1961, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 21, 1961 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Regular First Appeals Nos. 8-D and 21-D of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 21, 1961, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Regular First Appeals Nos. 8 D and 21-D of 1960. Ranganadham Chetty, S. K. Mehta and K. L. Mehta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 25, 1963 by SINHA C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963 March 25. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA C. J.-This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Punjab arises out of a suit for specific performance of a contract

facts.text: House property situate in Tughlak Road, New Delhi, belonging to the appellant, built on lease-hold plot granted by Government in 1935 to her predecessor-in-title.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Punjab arises out of a suit for specific performance of a contract of sale in respect of a house property situate in Tughlak Road, New Delhi, belonging to the appellant and built on a lease-hold plot granted by the Government in the year 1935, to her predecessor-in-title.

facts.text: Plaintiffs entered into contract of sale for the disputed property for Rs. 1,10,000 on September 4, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the plaintiffs entered into a contract of sale in respect of the disputed property for the sum of Rs. 1,10,000/-. The deed of agreement is dated September 4, 1956.

facts.text: Agreement provided vendor shall obtain permission of Chief Commissioner within two months.

anchor.surface_text: In so far as it is necessary to notice the terms of the document, the agreement provided that the vendor shall obtain the permission of the Chief Commissioner to the transaction of sale within two months of the agreement, and if the said permission was not forthcoming within that time, it was open to the purchasers to extend the date or to treat the agreement as cancelled.

facts.text: Necessary permission not forthcoming within stipulated time, purchasers extended time by another month.

anchor.surface_text: As the necessary permission was not forthcoming within the stipulated time, the purchasers extended the time by another month.

facts.text: Appellant made application to proper authorities for permission but withdrew it by letter dated April 12, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had made an application to the proper authorities for the necessary Permission, but withdrew her application to the Chief Commissioner by her letter dated April 12, 1957.

facts.text: Plaintiffs called upon defendant several times to fulfil agreement but she failed.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs called upon the defendant several times to fulfil her part of the agreement but she failed to do so.

facts.text: Plaintiffs averred they were always ready and willing to perform their part of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: It was averred on behalf of the plaintiffs that they had always been ready and willing to perform their part of the contract and that it was the defendant who had backed out of it.

facts.text: Suit filed for specific performance or alternatively damages Rs. 51,100.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, the suit for specific performance of the contract for sale or in the alternative for damages amounting to Rs. 51,100/-.

facts.text: Issue No. 8: Is the contract contingent or impossible of performance and uncertain and vague and therefore void?

anchor.surface_text: Issue No. 8 is as follows Is the contract contingent or impossible of performance and is uncertain and vague and is therefore void ?

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed suit for specific performance and permanent injunction, decreed Rs. 11,550 damages with costs against defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court in a very elaborate judgment dismissed the suit for specific performance of contract and for a permanent injunction and decreed the sum of Rs. 11,550/- by way of damages, with proportionate costs, against the defendant.

facts.text: Trial Court found plaintiffs ready and willing, defendant backed out, but refused specific performance as agreement inchoate without sanction.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Court found that the plaintiffs had been throughout ready and willing, indeed anxious, to perform their part of the contract, and that it was the defendant who backed out of it, it refused the main relief of specific performance of the contract on the ground that the agreement was inchoate in view of the fact that the previous sanction of the Chief Commissioner to the proposed transfer had not been obtained.

facts.text: High Court held agreement was completed contract subject to sanction, not inchoate, decreed specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on appeal came to the conclusion that the agreement was a completed contract for sale of the house in question, subject to the sanction of the Chief Commissioner before the sale transaction could be concluded, but that the Trial Court was in error in holding that the agreement was inchoate, and that, therefore, no decree for specific performance of the contract could be granted.

facts.text: High Court relied on Motilal v. Nanhelal (1930 LR 57 IA 333).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied mainly on the decision of their Lordships of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Motilal v. Nanhelal  1 , for coming to the conclusion that there was a completed contract between the parties

facts.text: High Court found vendor to blame for withdrawing application for sanction.

anchor.surface_text: and that the condition in the agreement that the vendor would obtain the sanction of the Chief Commissioner to the transaction of sale did not render the contract incomplete. In pursuance of that term in the agreement, the vendor had to obtain the sanction of the Chief Commissioner and as she had withdrawn her application for the necessary sanction, she was to blame

facts.text: High Court noted if sanction refused, plaintiff may not enforce decree, but not bar to granting it.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also pointed out that if the Chief Commissioner ultimately refused to grant the sanction to the sale, the plaintiff may not be able to enforced the decree for specific performance of the contract but that was not bar to the Court passing a decree for that relief.

facts.text: High Court recorded Rs. 5,775 as appropriate damages if specific performance fails.

anchor.surface_text: Though it was not necessary in the view the High Court took of  1930  L. R. 57 1. A. 333. the rights of the parties, it recorded a finding that a sum of Rs. 5,775/- would be the appropriate amount of damages

facts.text: Supreme Court held contract enforceable, not contingent.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground of attack on his appeal is that the contract is not enforceable being of a contingent nature and the contingency not having been fulfilled. In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention.

facts.text: Parties agreed to bind by terms of document executed between them.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the parties to the contract are concerned, they had agreed to bind themselves by the terms of the document executed between them.

facts.text: Defendant-vendor to make application for permission to Chief Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Under that document it was for the defendant- vendor to make the necessary application for the permission to the Chief Commissioner.

facts.text: Plaintiffs always ready and willing to perform, defendant wilfully refused.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings that the plaintiffs have always been ready and willing to perform their part Of the contract, and that it was the defendant who wilfully refused to perform her part of the contract,

facts.text: Time not of the essence of the contract.

anchor.surface_text: and that the time was not of the essence of the contract, the Court has got to enforce the terms of the contract

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court decree for specific performance, directed defendant to make application within one month.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the High Court was entirely correct in decreeing the suit for specific performance of the contract. The High Court should have further directed the defendant to make the necessary application for permission to the Chief Commissioner, which was implied in the contract between the parties.

facts.text: Defendant withdrew application without sufficient reasons.

anchor.surface_text: As the defendantvendor, without any sufficient reasons, withdrew the application already made to the Chief Commissioner

facts.text: Supreme Court decree: defendant to apply within one month from today, convey within one month of sanction; if refused, damages as per High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the decree to be prepared by this Court will add the clause that the defendant, within one month from to- day, shall make the necessary application to the Chief Commissioner or to such other competent authority as may have been empowered to grant the necessary sanction to transfers like the one in, question, and further that within one month of the receipt of that sanction she shall convey to the plaintiffs the property in suit. In the event of the sanction being refused, the plaintiffs shall be entitled to the damages as decreed by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant raised new pleas not raised in High Court, e.g., not fit case for specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to raise certain other pleas which had not been raised in the High Court, for example, that this was not a fit case in which specific performance of contract should be enforced by the Court.

facts.text: New plea not specifically raised in High Court, necessary facts not pleaded.

anchor.surface_text: This plea was not specifically raised in the High Court and the necessary facts were not pleaded in the pleadings.

facts.text: Supreme Court will not allow new plea raised for first time.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that this Court should not allow such a plea to be raised here for the first time.

holdings.text: The contract is enforceable and there is no substance in the contention that it is not enforceable being of a contingent nature and the contingency not having been fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: The main ground of attack on his appeal is that the contract is not enforceable being of a contingent nature and the contingency not having been fulfilled. In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention. So far as the parties to the contract are concerned, they had agreed to bind themselves by the terms of the document executed between them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties agreed to be bound by executed document terms requiring vendor to apply for Chief Commissioner's permission; vendor made and withdrew application

holdings.text: Plaintiffs always ready and willing to perform, defendant wilfully refused to perform her part, and time not of the essence of the contract

anchor.surface_text: On the findings that the plaintiffs have always been ready and willing to perform their part Of the contract, and that it was the defendant who wilfully refused to perform her part of the contract, and that the time was not of the essence of the contract, the Court has got to enforce the terms of the contract and to enjoin upon the defendant appellant to make the necessary application to the Chief Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting concurrent findings of lower courts on readiness, wilful default by defendant, and nature of time clause in sale contract

holdings.text: High Court was entirely correct in decreeing suit for specific performance of the contract

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the High Court was entirely correct in decreeing the suit for specific performance of the contract. The High Court should have further directed the defendant to make the necessary application for permission to the Chief Commissioner, which was implied in the contract between the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement is completed contract subject to sanction to be obtained by vendor; trial court erred in deeming it inchoate; plaintiffs ready, defendant defaulted

holdings.text: Defendant without sufficient reasons withdrew application already made to Chief Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: As the defendantvendor, without any sufficient reasons, withdrew the application already made to the Chief Commissioner the decree to be prepared by this Court will add the clause that the defendant, within one month from to- day, shall make the necessary application to the Chief Commissioner or to such other competent authority as may have been empowered to grant the necessary sanction to transfers like the one in, question,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defendant's own action caused failure to obtain permission; obligation implied in contract terms

holdings.text: Defendant shall apply for sanction within one month, convey property within one month of sanction; if refused, plaintiffs entitled to High Court decreed damages

anchor.surface_text: the decree to be prepared by this Court will add the clause that the defendant, within one month from to- day, shall make the necessary application to the Chief Commissioner or to such other competent authority as may have been empowered to grant the necessary sanction to transfers like the one in, question, and further that within one month of the receipt of that sanction she shall convey to the plaintiffs the property in suit. In the event of the sanction being refused, the plaintiffs shall be entitled to the damages as decreed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enforcing contract terms with timelines to remedy vendor's default; alternative damages if sanction refused

holdings.text: This Court should not allow new pleas raised for the first time which were not raised in High Court or pleaded

anchor.surface_text: The main ground of attack on his appeal is that the contract is not enforceable being of a contingent nature and the contingency not having been fulfilled. In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention. So far as the parties to the contract are concerned, they had agreed to bind themselves by the terms of the document executed between them.

anchor.surface_text: On the findings that the plaintiffs have always been ready and willing to perform their part Of the contract, and that it was the defendant who wilfully refused to perform her part of the contract, and that the time was not of the essence of the contract, the Court has got to enforce the terms of the contract and to enjoin upon the defendant appellant to make the necessary application to the Chief Commissioner.

In this view of the matter, the High Court was entirely correct in decreeing the suit for specific performance of the companytract. The High Court should have further directed the defendant to make the necessary application for permission to the Chief Commissioner, which was implied in the companytract between the parties. As the defendantvendor, without any sufficient reasons, withdrew the applic

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sought to raise certain other pleas which had not been raised in the High Court, for example, that this was not a fit case in which specific performance of contract should be enforced by the Court. This plea was not specifically raised in the High Court and the necessary facts were not pleaded in the pleadings. It is manifest that this Court should not allow such a plea to be raised here for the first time.

In this view of the matter, the High Court was entirely correct in decreeing the suit for specific performance of the companytract. The High Court should have further directed the defendant to make the necessary application for permission to the Chief Commissioner, which was implied in the companytract between the parties. As the defendantvendor, without any sufficient reasons, withdrew the applic
